body:
Hi @isiahmeadows, thanks for the issue. It looks like there's not enough information for us to know how to help you.

If you're reporting a bug, please be sure to include:

1. The version of ESLint you are using (run `eslint -v`)
2. What you did (the source code and ESLint configuration)
3. The actual ESLint output complete with numbers
4. What you expected to happen instead

Requesting a new rule? Please see [Proposing a New Rule](http://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/new-rules) for instructions.

Requesting a rule change? Please see [Proposing a Rule Change](http://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/rule-changes) for instructions.

If it's something else, please just provide as much additional information as possible. Thanks!

[//]: # (needs-info)
Closing because not enough information was provided to triage this issue.
Hi @isiahmeadows, it would really help us to have the information requested in this set of guidelines: [Proposing a New Rule](http://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/new-rules). Thanks!
@platinumazure I updated the original bug to include all that info.
@isiahmeadows Thank you! I'll go ahead and reopen this issue.

issue.title: New: Added max-lines-per-function rule (fixes #9842)

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: There is consensus among the team that this change meets the criteria for inclusion

labels.name: feature
labels.description: This change adds a new feature to ESLint

labels.name: archived due to age
labels.description: This issue has been archived; please open a new issue for any further discussion

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

body:
@isiahmeadows Very sorry for the long delay on this. Just wanted to ask, why is max-statements not sufficient for this sort of thing? (I realize that the counting is different-- statements vs lines-- but I'm asking why it's insufficient, not why it's different.)

I think I can probably get behind this, but I want to make sure there's a compelling case for implementing a line-based rule here when we should already have one for statements.

@platinumazure Some expressions (think: long method chains, JSX/hyperscript trees, functional pipelines) could take several lines, and `max-statements` would see only a few statements.

For a concrete example, in [this method](https://github.com/MithrilJS/mithril.js/blob/next/examples/dbmonster/mithril/app.js#L10-L34):

- `max-statements` would see exactly one statement, even though it's 25 lines long.
- `max-depth` would see no nested blocks, so it wouldn't be a limiting factor here, either.
- `max-nested-callbacks` would see a depth of at most 3, which is much lower than what most care about (default is 10, but I keep it at 4 for my personal projects).
- `complexity` is 1, so it has little-to-no use here.

Another concrete example, [this method](https://github.com/MithrilJS/mithril.js/blob/next/examples/todomvc/todomvc.js#L89-L125):

- `max-statements` would only see two statements, even though it's 36 lines long (a large method by any standard).
- `max-depth` would see a depth of at most 1 - there's no blocks, just calls and function expressions.
- `max-nested-callbacks` would see a depth of at most 3.
- The only rule that would have much of an effect limiting it would be `complexity`, which would rate the outermost at 7, the `.map` callback at 3, and the rest at 1 (default is 10).

So there's uses for it, just in the more pathological cases. (Of course, most code doesn't have this issue.)
